text: hello in this lesson we're going to talk
about the L sound this lesson will be in
three main parts first we're going to
look at L at the beginning of words then
we'll practice making L in the middle of
words and in the final part we'll take a
look at L at the end of words now many
students have asked for practice with R
and L together but here's the plan first
we'll look at L then we'll look at R
once you're comfortable making both
sounds separately we'll look at R and L
together in words like girl and world
okay let's begin by talking about how we
make the L sound the most important
thing is the position of your tongue I
want you to take the front part of your
tongue which is called the tip and touch
the backsides of your upper front teeth
slowly move the tip of your tongue up
until you touch a hard bump behind your
front teeth don't go too far up that's
called the roof of your mouth you want
the bump right behind your upper front
teeth
hold your tongue there that's the
starting position now I want you to blow
air out of your mouth keep your tongue
in place
you should feel air coming out on both
sides of your tongue if you feel the air
coming out on the left and the right
side of your tongue you know you have
the correct starting position now some
students confuse l when they're trying
to make T or D or they're confusing T
and D when they're trying to make L
here's the difference with T and D your
tip of the tongue does touch the same
hard bump but the rest of your tongue is
up it stops the airflow it stops air and
sound from coming out of your mouth
until you open it that's why we have
sounds like did
with L the tip of your tongue is
touching that heart bump but the sides
of your tongue are down and air can come
out the whole time it's never stopped so
let me try to explain that not just in
words but with a drawing I'm not a great
artist but I hope this helps so imagine
these are your upper front teeth these
are your lower teeth that's the roof of
your mouth and here is that hard bump so
you want to take the tip of your tongue
okay so it's touching like that okay
your tongue actually of course a little
bigger there on the bottom the tip of
your tongue is touching that hard bump
if it has a little bit of contact with
your upper front teeth that's okay but
the main point of contact is between the
tip and that hard bump behind your teeth
now let's talk about your lips you don't
want to pull them out and you don't want
them to make a tight little oh it's
something in between so open your mouth
and make a gentle rounding and relax a
little keep your tongue in place and
blow the air out now you need to add
your voice because L is a voiced
consonant that means that when you make
the sound you should always feel
vibration here in your throat so keep
the tongue against that bump gently
round your lips make sure the sides of
your tongue are down for the air to come
out and let me hear your voice now as we
practice we're going to exaggerate a lot
and that's okay because in practice it's
about teaching your mouth to work in
ways to move in ways that you're not
used to in your native language so we
talked about where your tongue is
how to position your lips and that you
need to use your voice we're going to
practice L at the beginning of words
that means that L is going to smoothly
move into the next sound a vowel sound
so as you move into the vowel sound that
tip of the tongue is going to drop down
for example let's take the word laugh
okay phonetically
look something like that it's a great
word because it reminds you that you
need to keep your mouth open it's very
difficult to laugh with your mouth
closed the valve sound in laugh is at ah
so what you need to do is begin as I
taught you by keeping the tip of your
tongue against that hard bump the sides
of your tongue or down but as you move
into the vowel sound you need to drop
your tongue to make the app so it's like
laughs laughs laughs you try it a few
times
laughs let's try some exercises first
we'll practice L in single words then
we'll practice L and phrases exercise 1
listen and repeat after me
love like look lemon left line lamp
lunch leaf life low long live let leg
late laugh loose
now let's move on to phrases groups of
words again listen and repeat after me
love lemons the left lane liked to laugh
a late lunch lots of light lots of
leaves look at the lamp the line on the
left long legs a loud laugh lost in life
a light lunch I also think is helpful to
practice L in first names it's good to
know how to pronounce people's names
correctly exercise 3 here are some boys
names listen and repeat after me
lamps landon lee leo leon lewis lex Liam
logan loom
Lucas Luthor
here we go with girls names listen and
repeat after me
lacy Lee Ann Lee Linda Lindsay Lisa Liz
Lois Louisa Lucy Lydia Lynn
you
